   208â†’### Option 2: Markdown Files with Frontmatter (Simple)
   209â†’
   210â†’If you don't want to use Astro Content Collections, you can manually load markdown files.
   211â†’
   212â†’#### Structure
   213â†’
   214â†’```
   215â†’src/
   216â†’  content/
   217â†’    docs/
   218â†’      getting-started/
   219â†’        welcome.md
   220â†’        connecting-accounts.md

   224â†’
   225â†’#### Implementation
   226â†’
   227â†’**File: `src/utils/docsLoader.ts`**
   228â†’
   229â†’```typescript
   230â†’import fs from 'fs';
   231â†’import path from 'path';
   232â†’import matter from 'gray-matter';
   233â†’import { marked } from 'marked';
   234â†’
   235â†’export interface DocMeta {
   236â†’  title: string;
   237â†’  description: string;
   238â†’  category: string;
   239â†’  order?: number;
   240â†’  tags?: string[];
   241â†’  relatedSections?: string[];
   242â†’}
   243â†’
   244â†’export interface Doc {
   245â†’  id: string;
   246â†’  slug: string;
   247â†’  meta: DocMeta;
   248â†’  content: string;
   249â†’  html: string;
   250â†’}
   251â†’
   252â†’export async function loadDocs(): Promise<Doc[]> {
   253â†’  const docsDir = path.join(process.cwd(), 'src/content/docs');
   254â†’  const docs: Doc[] = [];
   255â†’
   256â†’  function readDocsRecursively(dir: string, category: string = '') {
   257â†’    const files = fs.readdirSync(dir);
   258â†’
   259â†’    files.forEach(file => {
   260â†’      const filePath = path.join(dir, file);
   261â†’      const stat = fs.statSync(filePath);
   262â†’
   263â†’      if (stat.isDirectory()) {
   264â†’        readDocsRecursively(filePath, file);
   265â†’      } else if (file.endsWith('.md')) {
   266â†’        const fileContent = fs.readFileSync(filePath, 'utf-8');
   267â†’        const { data, content } = matter(fileContent);
   268â†’
   269â†’        const slug = path.relative(docsDir, filePath)
   270â†’          .replace(/\.md$/, '')
   271â†’          .replace(/\\/g, '/');
   272â†’
   273â†’        docs.push({
   274â†’          id: slug,
   275â†’          slug,
   276â†’          meta: data as DocMeta,
   277â†’          content,
   278â†’          html: marked(content),
   279â†’        });
   280â†’      }
   281â†’    });
   282â†’  }
   283â†’
   284â†’  readDocsRecursively(docsDir);
   285â†’  return docs;
   286â†’}
   287â†’
   288â†’export async function loadDoc(slug: string): Promise<Doc | null> {
   289â†’  const docs = await loadDocs();
   290â†’  return docs.find(doc => doc.slug === slug) || null;
   291â†’}
   292â†’```
   293â†’
   294â†’**Install dependencies:**

   299â†’
   300â†’#### Benefits
   301â†’
   302â†’âœ… Simple to understand
   303â†’âœ… No framework-specific knowledge needed
   304â†’âœ… Easy to migrate to other systems
   305â†’âš ï¸ Manual file loading and parsing

   310â†’### Option 3: Headless CMS (External Management)
   311â†’
   312â†’For non-technical team members or larger teams, use a headless CMS.
   313â†’
   314â†’#### Recommended Options
   315â†’
   316â†’**A. Sanity.io**
   317â†’- Real-time collaborative editing
   318â†’- Rich text editor with custom blocks
   319â†’- Built-in media management
   320â†’- Versioning and rollback
   321â†’- Free tier available
   322â†’
   323â†’**B. Strapi**
   324â†’- Self-hosted option
   325â†’- Full REST/GraphQL API
   326â†’- Role-based access control
   327â†’- Media library
   328â†’- Open source
   329â†’
   330â†’**C. Contentful**
   331â†’- Enterprise-grade
   332â†’- Multi-language support
   333â†’- Content modeling
   334â†’- Asset optimization
   335â†’
   336â†’#### Implementation Example (Sanity)
   337â†’
   338â†’**File: `src/lib/sanity.ts`**
   339â†’
   340â†’```typescript
   341â†’import { createClient } from '@sanity/client';
   342â†’
   343â†’export const sanityClient = createClient({
   344â†’  projectId: import.meta.env.SANITY_PROJECT_ID,
   345â†’  dataset: 'production',
   346â†’  useCdn: true,
   347â†’  apiVersion: '2024-01-01',
   348â†’});
   349â†’
   350â†’export async function getDocs() {
   351â†’  return sanityClient.fetch(`
   352â†’    *[_type == "documentation"] | order(order asc) {
   353â†’      _id,
   354â†’      title,
   355â†’      description,
   356â†’      category,
   357â†’      slug,
   358â†’      content,
   359â†’      tags,
   360â†’      relatedSections
   361â†’    }
   362â†’  `);
   363â†’}
   364â†’
   365â†’export async function getDoc(slug: string) {
   366â†’  return sanityClient.fetch(`
   367â†’    *[_type == "documentation" && slug.current == $slug][0]
   368â†’  `, { slug });
   369â†’}
   370â†’```
   371â†’
   372â†’#### Benefits
   373â†’
   374â†’âœ… Non-technical users can edit
   375â†’âœ… WYSIWYG editor
   376â†’âœ… Media management
   377â†’âœ… Versioning/rollback

   384â†’### Option 4: Hybrid Approach (Git + CMS)
   385â†’
   386â†’Use a Git-based CMS like **Tina.io** or **Decap CMS** (formerly Netlify CMS) that edits markdown files in your repository.
   387â†’
   388â†’#### Benefits
   389â†’

   393â†’âœ… Open source

   442â†’            required: true,
   443â†’          },
   444â†’          {
   445â†’            type: 'rich-text',

   447â†’            label: 'Body',

   461â†’## Recommendation Summary
   462â†’
   463â†’### Use **Astro Content Collections** if:
   464â†’- You're already using Astro (you are!)
   465â†’- Team is technical/comfortable with Git
   466â†’- Want type safety and validation
   467â†’- Need fast build times
   468â†’- Want markdown/MDX support

   470â†’### Use **Headless CMS** (Sanity/Strapi) if:

   477â†’### Use **Git-based CMS** (Tina/Decap) if:

   483â†’## Implementation Plan

   496â†’**Phase 3: Scale**

# Documentation System Proposal ## Overview This proposal outlines a centralized documentation system that can be used both as a standalone page and in modal views throughout the app. Users can access full documentation from the landing page, while "Learn More" buttons throughout the dashboard open contextual documentation modals without navigation. ## Content Management Strategy **Using Astro Content Collections (Recommended)** Documentation content will be stored as markdown files using Astro's built-in Content Collections feature. This provides: - âœ… Clean separation of content and code - âœ… Built-in TypeScript types from Zod schemas - âœ… Fast builds with automatic optimization - âœ… Easy content editing with markdown files - âœ… Version control friendly (no noisy diffs) - âœ… Compatible with existing Astro 5.13.7 setup - âœ… No additional dependencies beyond `marked` for Vue components **Directory Structure:** ``` src/ content/ docs/ getting-started/ welcome.md connecting-accounts.md features/ creating-posts.md workflows/ workflow-basics.md integrations/ platform-integrations.md analytics/ analytics-dashboard.md advanced/ api-access.md config.ts # Zod schemas for validation ``` ## Architecture Design ### 1. Content Collection Configuration **File: `src/content/config.ts`** ```typescript import { defineCollection, z } from 'astro:content'; const docsCollection = defineCollection({ type: 'content', schema: z.object({ title: z.string(), description: z.string(), category: z.enum(['getting-started', 'features', 'workflows', 'integrations', 'analytics', 'advanced']), order: z.number().optional(), tags: z.array(z.string()).optional(), relatedSections: z.array(z.string()).optional(), lastUpdated: z.date().optional(), author: z.string().optional(), }), }); export const collections = { docs: docsCollection, }; ``` **Example Markdown File: `src/content/docs/getting-started/welcome.md`** ```markdown --- title: Welcome to Socialaize description: Get started with social media management made simple category: getting-started order: 1 tags: [basics, introduction] relatedSections: [connecting-accounts, creating-posts] lastUpdated: 2024-01-15 --- # Welcome to Socialaize Socialaize is your all-in-one social media management platform... ## Quick Start 1. # Documentation System Proposal

## Overview

This proposal outlines a centralized documentation system that can be used both as a standalone page and in modal views throughout the app. Users can access full documentation from the landing page, while "Learn More" buttons throughout the dashboard open contextual documentation modals without navigation.

## Content Management Strategy

**Using Astro Content Collections (Recommended)**

Documentation content will be stored as markdown files using Astro's built-in Content Collections feature. This provides:

- âœ… Clean separation of content and code
- âœ… Built-in TypeScript types from Zod schemas
- âœ… Fast builds with automatic optimization
- âœ… Easy content editing with markdown files
- âœ… Version control friendly (no noisy diffs)
- âœ… Compatible with existing Astro 5.13.7 setup
- âœ… No additional dependencies beyond `marked` for Vue components

**Directory Structure:**
```
src/
  content/
    docs/
      getting-started/
        welcome.md
        connecting-accounts.md
      features/
        creating-posts.md
      workflows/
        workflow-basics.md
      integrations/
        platform-integrations.md
      analytics/
        analytics-dashboard.md
      advanced/
        api-access.md
    config.ts  # Zod schemas for validation
```

## Architecture Design

### 1. Content Collection Configuration

**File: `src/content/config.ts`**

```typescript
import { defineCollection, z } from 'astro:content';

const docsCollection = defineCollection({
  type: 'content',
  schema: z.object({
    title: z.string(),
    description: z.string(),
    category: z.enum(['getting-started', 'features', 'workflows', 'integrations', 'analytics', 'advanced']),
    order: z.number().optional(),
    tags: z.array(z.string()).optional(),
    relatedSections: z.array(z.string()).optional(),
    lastUpdated: z.date().optional(),
    author: z.string().optional(),
  }),
});

export const collections = {
  docs: docsCollection,
};
```

**Example Markdown File: `src/content/docs/getting-started/welcome.md`**

# Documentation System Implementation - Master Plan

## Task Overview
Implement complete documentation system using Astro Content Collections, Vue 3 components, and Tailwind CSS with both modal and full-page views.

## Technology Detection
- **Astro 5.13.7** - SSR with Cloudflare adapter
- **Vue 3.5.17** - Component framework
- **TypeScript 5.8.3** - Type safety
- **Tailwind CSS 4.1.11** - Styling
- **Nanostores** - State management
- **Zod** - Schema validation (already available)

## Required Agents
1. **@astro-vue-architect** - Primary implementation (Astro + Vue + SSR)

   - Active category atom for full page

   - Uses docSlug prop for single doc or shows all with tabs

   - Footer with product/resources/company/legal links
   - Mobile responsive (hamburger menu)
   - Dark mode support throughout

   - Pass to DocsPageView component

   - Use DocContent component
   - Show all categories with tab navigation
   - Props: docs, categories

4. **Update landing page navigation**:
   - Find main navigation file (likely in `src/pages/index.astro` or layout)
   - Add link to `/docs` in header navigation

- Test results for all functionality

# Documentation System Implementation - Master Plan

## Task Overview
Implement complete documentation system using Astro Content Collections, Vue 3 components, and Tailwind CSS with both modal and full-page views.

## Technology Detection
- **Astro 5.13.7** - SSR with Cloudflare adapter
- **Vue 3.5.17** - Component framework
- **TypeScript 5.8.3** - Type safety
- **Tailwind CSS 4.1.11** - Styling
- **Nanostores** - State management
- **Zod** - Schema validation (already available)

## Required Agents
1. **@astro-vue-architect** - Primary implementation (Astro + Vue + SSR)
2. **@typescript-master** - Type safety and TypeScript configuration

## Execution Strategy

### Phase A: Foundation & Configuration (Parallel)
**Status:** â³ Pending
**Agent:** @typescript-master
**Dependencies:** None

# Documentation System Proposal ## Overview This proposal outlines a centralized documentation system that can be used both as a standalone page and in modal views throughout the app. Users can access full documentation from the landing page, while "Learn More" buttons throughout the dashboard open contextual documentation modals without navigation. ## Content Management Strategy **Using Astro Content Collections (Recommended)** Documentation content will be stored as markdown files using Astro's built-in Content Collections feature. This provides: - âœ… Clean separation of content and code - âœ… Built-in TypeScript types from Zod schemas - âœ… Fast builds with automatic optimization - âœ… Easy content editing with markdown files - âœ… Version control friendly (no noisy diffs) - âœ… Compatible with existing Astro 5.13.7 setup - âœ… No additional dependencies beyond `marked` for Vue components **Directory Structure:** ``` src/ content/ docs/ getting-started/ welcome.md connecting-accounts.md features/ creating-posts.md workflows/ workflow-basics.md integrations/ platform-integrations.md analytics/ analytics-dashboard.md advanced/ api-access.md config.ts # Zod schemas for validation ``` ## Architecture Design ### 1. CRITICAL: Read @docPlan/DocsSystemProposal.md first before starting any work!

Then read @.temp/documentation-system/MASTER_PLAN.md for your assigned tasks.

## Your Mission: Phases B, C, D, E - Components, Content, Integration & Pages

You are responsible for building all Vue components, writing documentation content, creating modal integration, and building the full documentation page.

### Wait for Foundation First:
BEFORE starting, verify these files exist (created by typescript-master):
- `src/content/config.ts`
- `src/content/docs/categories.ts`
- Directory: `src/content/docs/` with subdirectories

### Phase B: Core Vue Components
1. **Create `src/stores/docsStore.ts`**:
   - Use nanostores (atom)
   - Modal state: { isOpen: boolean, docSlug?: string }
   - Export: docsModalState, openDocsModal(), closeDocsModal()
   - Active category atom for full page

2. **Create `src/components/vue/docs/DocContent.vue`**:
   - Main content container
   - Works in BOTH modal and full-page contexts
   - Uses docSlug prop for single doc or shows all with tabs
   - Tab navigation for categories
   - Renders DocSection components

3. **Create `src/components/vue/docs/DocSection.vue`**:
   - Renders individual doc with `marked` library
   - Shows title, description, rendered markdown content
   - Related sections links at bottom
   - Props: doc (CollectionEntry<'docs'>), allDocs

4. **Create `src/components/vue/buttons/LearnMoreButton.vue`**:
   - Trigger button component
   - Props: sectionId, text (optional)
   - Calls openDocsModal(sectionId) on click
   - Icon + text style

### Phase C: Content Creation
Create 7 markdown files with proper frontmatter in `src/content/docs/`:
1. `getting-started/welcome.md`
2. `getting-started/connecting-accounts.md`
3. `features/creating-posts.md`
4. `workflows/workflow-basics.md`
5. `integrations/platform-integrations.md`
6. `analytics/analytics-dashboard.md`
7. `advanced/api-access.md`

Each must have:
- Frontmatter: title, description, category, order, tags, relatedSections
- Markdown content explaining the feature
- Relevant headings (##) for TOC generation

### Phase D: Modal Integration
1. **Create `src/components/vue/modals/DocsModal.vue`**:
   - Use existing `BaseModal.vue` component
   - Accept props: docs (CollectionEntry<'docs'>[]), categories
   - Use docsModalState from store
   - Render DocContent inside modal
   - Footer with "View full documentation" link and close button
   - Use existing OutlineButton component

2. **Update `src/layouts/DashLayout.astro`**:
   - Import `getCollection` from 'astro:content'
   - Fetch all docs: `await getCollection('docs')`
   - Import categories from categories.ts
   - Add DocsModal component with `client:load` and pass docs + categories props
   - Place after existing modals

### Phase E: Full Documentation Page
1. **Create `src/layouts/DocsLayout.astro`**:
   - 3-column layout: left sidebar (navigation), main content, right sidebar (TOC)
   - Sticky header with logo, search placeholder, Dashboard link, Get Started CTA
   - Left sidebar: category navigation, quick links
   - Right sidebar: auto-generated TOC from h2/h3 headings
   - Footer with product/resources/company/legal links
   - Mobile responsive (hamburger menu)
   - Dark mode support throughout

2. **Create `src/pages/docs/index.astro`**:
   - Public page (no authentication required)
   - Use DocsLayout
   - Fetch all docs with `getCollection('docs')`
   - Pass to DocsPageView component

3. **Create `src/components/vue/views/docs/DocsPageView.vue`**:
   - Use DocContent component
   - Show all categories with tab navigation
   - Props: docs, categories

4. **Update landing page navigation**:
   - Find main navigation file (likely in `src/pages/index.astro` or layout)
   - Add link to `/docs` in header navigation

### Phase F: Testing
After all components are built:
1. Test markdown rendering with Tailwind prose styles
2. Verify dark mode works
3. Test modal opening from dashboard (create test trigger if needed)
4. Check mobile responsiveness
5. Validate related sections linking
6. Verify SSR builds successfully

### Critical Requirements:
- Use EXISTING BaseModal.vue component (in `src/components/vue/modals/`)
- Use EXISTING OutlineButton.vue (in `src/components/vue/buttons/`)
- Follow exact component structure from proposal
- Ensure SSR compatibility (use `client:load` for Vue components in Astro)
- All TypeScript types must be correct
- Support both modal and full-page contexts in DocContent

### What to Report Back:
- List of all files created/modified
- Any challenges with SSR/hydration
- Whether modal integration works
- Whether full docs page renders correctly
- Test results for all functionality

Start AFTER typescript-master completes foundation, then build systematically following the phases.

Implement complete documentation system using Astro Content Collections, Vue 3 components, and Tailwind CSS with both modal and full-page views.

# Connecting Your Social Accounts

Connect all your social media accounts to Socialaize in just a few clicks. Our secure OAuth integration ensures your credentials stay safe.

## Supported Platforms

Socialaize supports all major social media platforms:

- **Facebook** - Pages, Groups, and Personal Profiles
- **Instagram** - Business and Creator accounts
- **Twitter/X** - Personal and Business accounts
- **LinkedIn** - Personal Profiles and Company Pages
- **TikTok** - Creator and Business accounts
- **YouTube** - Channels and Brand accounts
- **Pinterest** - Personal and Business accounts
- **Mastodon** - All instances
- **Threads** - Meta's text-based platform
- **Bluesky** - Decentralized social network

## How to Connect an Account

### Step 1: Navigate to Accounts

1. Click on **Accounts** in the main navigation
2. Click the **Add Account** button
3. Select your desired platform from the list

### Step 2: Authorize the Connection

1. You'll be redirected to the platform's authorization page
2. Log in with your account credentials (if not already logged in)
3. Review the permissions Socialaize requests
4. Click **Authorize** or **Allow**

### Step 3: Confirm Connection

1. You'll be redirected back to Socialaize
2. Your account will appear in your Accounts list
3. You can now use this account for posting and analytics

## Managing Connected Accounts

### View Account Details

Click on any connected account to view:

- **Account information** - Username, profile picture, follower count
- **Connection status** - Active, expired, or requires reauthorization
- **Permissions** - What actions Socialaize can perform
- **Usage statistics** - Posts scheduled, published, and engagement

### Reconnect an Account

If an account's authorization expires:

1. Click the **Reconnect** button next to the account
2. Follow the authorization steps again
3. Your previous settings and scheduled posts remain intact

### Remove an Account

To disconnect an account:

1. Click on the account you want to remove
2. Click the **Remove Account** button
3. Confirm the removal
4. Note: Scheduled posts for this account will be cancelled

## Permissions Explained

### Why We Need Permissions

Each platform requires specific permissions to enable features:

- **Read access** - View your account information and analytics
- **Write access** - Post content on your behalf
- **Analytics access** - Retrieve engagement metrics and insights
- **Media access** - Upload images and videos

### Revoking Permissions

You can revoke Socialaize's access at any time:

1. Visit the platform's app settings
2. Find Socialaize in the connected apps list
3. Click **Revoke Access**
4. The account will be automatically disconnected in Socialaize

## Troubleshooting

### Connection Failed

If you encounter issues connecting:

- **Check browser permissions** - Allow popups for socialaize.com
- **Clear cookies** - Sometimes old sessions interfere
- **Try incognito mode** - Eliminates browser extension conflicts
- **Contact support** - We're here to help!

### Account Not Appearing

If your account doesn't show after authorization:

1. Wait 30 seconds and refresh the page
2. Check if the platform sent a confirmation email
3. Verify you authorized the correct account
4. Contact support if the issue persists

### Reauthorization Required

Some platforms require periodic reauthorization:

- **Facebook/Instagram** - Every 60 days
- **Twitter/X** - Every 90 days
- **LinkedIn** - Every 180 days
- **Other platforms** - Varies by platform

You'll receive email notifications before authorization expires.

## Best Practices

- **Connect multiple accounts** - Manage all platforms from one place
- **Use business accounts** - Access advanced features and analytics
- **Keep credentials secure** - Never share your login details
- **Monitor connection status** - Ensure accounts stay connected
- **Reauthorize promptly** - Maintain uninterrupted service

- [Set up automated workflows](/docs#workflow-basics)
- [View analytics for your accounts](/docs#analytics-dashboard)

# Workflow Automation Basics

Automate your social media management with intelligent workflows that save time and ensure consistency across all your platforms.

## What are Workflows?

Workflows are automated sequences of actions triggered by specific events. Think of them as "if this, then that" rules for your social media.

### Common Workflow Examples

- **Cross-posting** - Instagram post automatically shared to Twitter and Facebook
- **Content repurposing** - Blog post converted to social media posts
- **Engagement automation** - Auto-reply to mentions or comments
- **Analytics tracking** - Automated performance reports
- **Content curation** - Auto-share content from specific sources

## Workflow Components

### Triggers

Events that start a workflow:

- **New post** - When you publish on a platform
- **Schedule** - Time-based (daily, weekly, etc.)
- **Mention** - When someone mentions your account
- **Keyword** - Specific words or hashtags detected
- **Webhook** - External system notification

### Actions

What happens when triggered:

- **Create post** - Publish to platforms
- **Modify content** - Edit text, images, or videos
- **Send notification** - Email or in-app alert
- **Store data** - Save to database or export
- **Call API** - Integrate with external services

### Conditions

Rules that determine if actions execute:

- **Platform check** - Only for specific platforms
- **Content type** - Text, image, or video posts
- **Time-based** - Specific days or hours
- **Engagement level** - Based on likes/comments
- **Custom logic** - Advanced conditional rules

## Creating Your First Workflow

### Step 1: Choose a Template

Start with pre-built workflows:

1. Navigate to **Workflows** in the dashboard
2. Click **Create Workflow**

   - Analytics reports

### Step 2: Configure Trigger

3. Set trigger conditions
4. Test trigger to verify it works

### Step 3: Add Actions

### Step 4: Set Conditions (Optional)

# API Access

Access Socialaize's powerful API to integrate social media management into your own applications, workflows, and systems.

## Getting Started

### API Access Requirements

To use the Socialaize API, you need:

- **Active Socialaize account** - Pro or Enterprise plan
- **API key** - Generated from your account settings
- **Technical knowledge** - Basic understanding of REST APIs
- **Development environment** - For testing and integration

### Generating API Keys

Create your API credentials:

1. Navigate to **Settings** > **Developer** > **API Keys**
2. Click **Generate New API Key**
3. Name your key (e.g., "Production App", "Testing")
4. Select permissions (read, write, admin)
5. Copy and securely store your key
6. Note: Keys are only shown once!

### Authentication

All API requests require authentication:

```bash
curl -H "Authorization: Bearer YOUR_API_KEY" \
     https://api.socialaize.com/v1/posts
```

**Security Best Practices**
- Never commit API keys to version control
- Use environment variables for keys
- Rotate keys regularly (every 90 days)
- Use different keys for production and development
- Revoke keys immediately if compromised

## API Endpoints

### Base URL

All API requests use:
```
https://api.socialaize.com/v1/
```

### Rate Limits

API usage is limited to ensure fair access:

- **Free Plan**: 100 requests/hour
- **Pro Plan**: 1,000 requests/hour
- **Enterprise Plan**: 10,000 requests/hour
- **Custom**: Contact sales for higher limits

Rate limit headers returned with each request:
```
X-RateLimit-Limit: 1000
X-RateLimit-Remaining: 999
X-RateLimit-Reset: 1633024800
```

## Core Endpoints

### Posts

**List Posts**
```http
GET /v1/posts
```

Query parameters:
- `platform` - Filter by platform (facebook, instagram, etc.)
- `status` - Filter by status (draft, scheduled, published)
- `limit` - Number of results (max 100)
- `offset` - Pagination offset

**Create Post**
```http
POST /v1/posts
Content-Type: application/json

  "platforms": ["facebook", "instagram"],
  "content": "Your post text",
  "media": ["https://example.com/image.jpg"],
  "schedule_time": "2024-10-15T14:30:00Z"
}
```

**Get Post**
```http
GET /v1/posts/{post_id}
```

**Update Post**
```http
PUT /v1/posts/{post_id}
Content-Type: application/json

{
  "content": "Updated text",
  "schedule_time": "2024-10-15T15:00:00Z"
}

## Webhooks

### Setting Up Webhooks

Receive real-time notifications for events:

1. Go to **Settings** > **Developer** > **Webhooks**
2. Click **Add Webhook**
3. Enter your endpoint URL
4. Select events to subscribe to
5. Save and test webhook

### Webhook Events

Available webhook events:

**Post Events**
- `post.created` - New post created
- `post.published` - Post went live
- `post.failed` - Post failed to publish
- `post.deleted` - Post was deleted

**Account Events**
- `account.connected` - New account connected
- `account.disconnected` - Account removed
- `account.error` - Account authorization issue

**Analytics Events**
- `analytics.updated` - New analytics data available
- `analytics.milestone` - Goal or milestone reached

**Workflow Events**
- `workflow.executed` - Workflow ran
- `workflow.failed` - Workflow encountered error

### Webhook Payload

Example webhook payload:

```json
{
  "event": "post.published",
  "timestamp": "2024-10-15T14:30:00Z",
  "data": {
    "post_id": "abc123",
    "platform": "facebook",
    "account_id": "def456",
    "content": "Your post text",
    "url": "https://facebook.com/..."
  }
}
```

### Verifying Webhooks

Verify webhook authenticity:

```python
import hmac
import hashlib

def verify_webhook(payload, signature, secret):
    expected = hmac.new(
        secret.encode(),
        payload.encode(),
        hashlib.sha256
    ).hexdigest()
    return hmac.compare_digest(expected, signature)
```

Header containing signature:
```
X-Socialaize-Signature: sha256=abc123...
```

## Error Handling

### Error Response Format

All errors return consistent format:

```json
{
  "error": {
    "code": "invalid_request",
    "message": "Missing required field: content",
    "details": {
      "field": "content",
      "reason": "required"
    }
  }
}
```

### Common Error Codes

- `400` - Bad Request (invalid parameters)
- `401` - Unauthorized (invalid or missing API key)
- `403` - Forbidden (insufficient permissions)
- `404` - Not Found (resource doesn't exist)
- `429` - Too Many Requests (rate limit exceeded)
- `500` - Internal Server Error (contact support)
- `503` - Service Unavailable (temporary outage)

### Retry Logic

Implement exponential backoff:

```javascript
async function retryRequest(fn, maxRetries = 3) {
  for (let i = 0; i < maxRetries; i++) {
    try {
      return await fn();
    } catch (error) {
      if (error.status !== 429 && error.status !== 503) {
        throw error;
      }
      
      const delay = Math.pow(2, i) * 1000; // 1s, 2s, 4s
      await new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, delay));
    }
  }
  
  throw new Error('Max retries exceeded');
}
```

## Best Practices

### Performance Optimization

**Batch Requests**
```javascript
// Instead of multiple individual requests
const postIds = ['id1', 'id2', 'id3'];
const posts = await Promise.all(
  postIds.map(id => client.posts.get(id))
);

// Use batch endpoint (when available)
const posts = await client.posts.getBatch(postIds);
```

**Caching**
```javascript
const cache = new Map();

async function getCachedPost(postId) {
  if (cache.has(postId)) {
    return cache.get(postId);
  }
  
  const post = await client.posts.get(postId);
  cache.set(postId, post);
  
  // Expire cache after 5 minutes
  setTimeout(() => cache.delete(postId), 5 * 60 * 1000);
  
  return post;
}
```

**Pagination**
```javascript
async function getAllPosts() {
  let allPosts = [];
  let offset = 0;
  const limit = 100;
  
  while (true) {
    const posts = await client.posts.list({ limit, offset });
    allPosts = allPosts.concat(posts);
    
    if (posts.length < limit) break;
    offset += limit;
  }
  
  return allPosts;
}
```

# Documentation System Proposal ## Overview This proposal outlines a centralized documentation system that can be used both as a standalone page and in modal views throughout the app. Users can access full documentation from the landing page, while "Learn More" buttons throughout the dashboard open contextual documentation modals without navigation. ## Content Management Strategy **Using Astro Content Collections (Recommended)** Documentation content will be stored as markdown files using Astro's built-in Content Collections feature. This provides: - âœ… Clean separation of content and code - âœ… Built-in TypeScript types from Zod schemas - âœ… Fast builds with automatic optimization - âœ… Easy content editing with markdown files - âœ… Version control friendly (no noisy diffs) - âœ… Compatible with existing Astro 5.13.7 setup - âœ… No additional dependencies beyond `marked` for Vue components **Directory Structure:** ``` src/ content/ docs/ getting-started/ welcome.md connecting-accounts.md features/ creating-posts.md workflows/ workflow-basics.md integrations/ platform-integrations.md analytics/ analytics-dashboard.md advanced/ api-access.md config.ts # Zod schemas for validation ``` ## Architecture Design ### 1. relatedSections: [getting-started/connecting-accounts, features/creating-posts]

# Welcome to Socialaize

Socialaize is your all-in-one social media management platform that streamlines content creation, scheduling, and analytics across all major social networks.

## Quick Start

Get up and running in just a few minutes:

1. **Connect your social accounts** - Link all your platforms in one place
2. **Create your first post** - Use our intuitive editor to craft engaging content
3. **Schedule or publish** - Choose to post immediately or schedule for optimal times
4. **Track performance** - Monitor engagement and analytics in real-time

## Key Features

### Multi-Platform Posting
Manage all your social accounts from a single dashboard. Post to Facebook, Instagram, Twitter/X, LinkedIn, TikTok, YouTube, Pinterest, Mastodon, Threads, and Bluesky simultaneously.

### AI-Powered Workflows
Automate repetitive tasks with intelligent workflows that adapt content for each platform, suggest optimal posting times, and enhance your content with AI.

### Advanced Analytics
Gain insights into your social media performance with comprehensive analytics, custom dashboards, and detailed reports.

### Team Collaboration
Work together seamlessly with team members, assign roles, and manage permissions across your organization.

## What Makes Socialaize Different?

- **No Learning Curve** - Intuitive interface designed for ease of use
- **Powerful Automation** - Save time with smart workflows and AI assistance
- **Comprehensive Platform Support** - All major social networks in one place
- **Real-Time Sync** - Changes reflect instantly across all platforms
- **Privacy First** - Your data is encrypted and secure

## Next Steps

Ready to dive in? Here's what to do next:

- [Connect your first social account](/docs#connecting-accounts)
- [Learn about creating posts](/docs#creating-posts)
- [Explore AI workflows](/docs#workflow-basics)
- [Set up your analytics dashboard](/docs#analytics-dashboard)

Need help? Our [support team](mailto:support@socialaize.com) is here for you 24/7.

---
title: Workflow Automation Basics
description: Learn how to automate your social media with powerful workflows
category: workflows
order: 1
tags: [automation, workflows, ai, triggers]
relatedSections: [features/creating-posts, integrations/platform-integrations]

# Workflow Automation Basics

Automate your social media management with intelligent workflows that save time and ensure consistency across all your platforms.

## What are Workflows?

Workflows are automated sequences of actions triggered by specific events. Think of them as "if this, then that" rules for your social media.

### Common Workflow Examples

- **Cross-posting** - Instagram post automatically shared to Twitter and Facebook
- **Content repurposing** - Blog post converted to social media posts
- **Engagement automation** - Auto-reply to mentions or comments
- **Analytics tracking** - Automated performance reports
- **Content curation** - Auto-share content from specific sources

## Workflow Components

### Triggers

Events that start a workflow:

- **New post** - When you publish on a platform
- **Schedule** - Time-based (daily, weekly, etc.)
- **Mention** - When someone mentions your account
- **Keyword** - Specific words or hashtags detected
- **Webhook** - External system notification

### Actions

What happens when triggered:

- **Create post** - Publish to platforms
- **Modify content** - Edit text, images, or videos
- **Send notification** - Email or in-app alert
- **Store data** - Save to database or export
- **Call API** - Integrate with external services

### Conditions

Rules that determine if actions execute:

- **Platform check** - Only for specific platforms
- **Content type** - Text, image, or video posts
- **Time-based** - Specific days or hours
- **Engagement level** - Based on likes/comments
- **Custom logic** - Advanced conditional rules

## Creating Your First Workflow

### Step 1: Choose a Template

Start with pre-built workflows:

1. Navigate to **Workflows** in the dashboard
2. Click **Create Workflow**
3. Browse workflow templates:
   - Cross-platform posting
   - Content repurposing
   - Engagement automation
   - Analytics reports
4. Select a template or start from scratch

### Step 2: Configure Trigger

Set up what starts the workflow:

1. Choose trigger type (post, schedule, event)
2. Select source platform (if applicable)
3. Set trigger conditions
4. Test trigger to verify it works

### Step 3: Add Actions

Define what happens:

1. Click **Add Action**
2. Choose action type from list
3. Configure action parameters:
   - Target platforms
   - Content modifications
   - Timing settings
4. Preview action results

### Step 4: Set Conditions (Optional)

Add conditional logic:

1. Click **Add Condition**
2. Define condition rules
3. Choose what happens if condition passes/fails
4. Test with sample data

### Step 5: Test and Activate

Ensure workflow works correctly:

1. Use **Test Mode** with sample data
2. Review test results
3. Make adjustments if needed
4. Click **Activate Workflow**
5. Monitor initial runs

## Popular Workflow Templates

### Auto-Repost from Instagram

Automatically share Instagram posts to other platforms:

- **Trigger** - New Instagram post
- **Actions** - 
  - Extract image and caption
  - Adapt caption for Twitter (shorten if needed)
  - Post to Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn
  - Add custom hashtags per platform

### Blog to Social Media

Convert blog posts to social content:

- **Trigger** - New blog post published (RSS or webhook)
- **Actions** -
  - Extract title, excerpt, and featured image
  - Create multiple post variations
  - Schedule posts across platforms
  - Track performance

### Engagement Response

Automate responses to engagement:

- **Trigger** - Mention or comment received
- **Conditions** - Filter spam and inappropriate content
- **Actions** -
  - Send auto-reply
  - Notify team member
  - Log interaction for CRM

### Performance Report

Automated analytics reports:

- **Trigger** - Weekly schedule (Monday 9 AM)
- **Actions** -
  - Gather metrics from all platforms
  - Generate summary report
  - Email to team
  - Save to analytics dashboard

## AI-Enhanced Workflows

### Content Optimization

AI analyzes and improves content:

- **Tone adjustment** - Match brand voice
- **Length optimization** - Perfect for each platform
- **Hashtag suggestions** - Trending and relevant
- **Translation** - Multi-language posting

### Smart Scheduling

AI determines best posting times:

- **Audience analysis** - When followers are active
- **Competition tracking** - Avoid crowded times
- **Historical data** - Based on past performance
- **Platform algorithms** - Optimized for each network

### Trend Detection

Monitor and capitalize on trends:

- **Keyword tracking** - Industry-specific terms
- **Viral content** - Identify trending posts
- **Competitor monitoring** - Track rival activity
- **Auto-engagement** - Like, comment, or share

## Advanced Workflow Features

### Multi-Step Workflows

Chain multiple actions:

1. Post to Instagram
2. Wait 5 minutes
3. Post to Twitter with Instagram link
4. Wait 1 hour
5. Share to Facebook

### Branching Logic

Different paths based on conditions:

```
If engagement > 100 likes:
  â†’ Boost post with ads
  â†’ Send success notification
Else:
  â†’ Try different caption
  â†’ Reschedule for peak time
```

### Error Handling

What happens if something fails:

- **Retry logic** - Attempt action again
- **Fallback actions** - Alternative workflow path
- **Notifications** - Alert team of failures
- **Logging** - Track for debugging

### Workflow Variables

Dynamic content using placeholders:

- `{{username}}` - User's display name
- `{{platform}}` - Current platform
- `{{date}}` - Current date/time
- `{{custom_field}}` - Your custom data

## Workflow Management

### Monitoring Active Workflows

Track workflow performance:

- **Execution history** - See all workflow runs
- **Success rate** - Percentage of successful runs
- **Error logs** - Identify and fix issues
- **Resource usage** - Monitor API calls and limits

### Editing Workflows

Modify existing workflows:

1. Go to **Workflows** dashboard
2. Select workflow to edit
3. Make changes to triggers, actions, or conditions
4. Save changes
5. Optionally deactivate while editing

### Pausing and Deleting

Manage workflow lifecycle:

- **Pause** - Temporarily stop without deleting
- **Duplicate** - Copy workflow to modify
- **Archive** - Keep for reference but inactive
- **Delete** - Permanently remove workflow

## Best Practices

### Start Simple

- Begin with one-step workflows
- Add complexity gradually
- Test thoroughly before activating
- Monitor performance regularly

### Use Appropriate Triggers

- Choose specific, relevant triggers
- Avoid triggers that fire too frequently
- Test triggers before full deployment
- Set up fallback triggers

### Optimize Actions

- Minimize API calls
- Batch actions when possible
- Use caching for frequently accessed data
- Implement rate limiting

### Handle Errors Gracefully

- Always include error handling
- Set up notification for failures
- Log errors for debugging
- Implement retry logic

### Monitor Performance

- Check workflow execution logs
- Review success/failure rates
- Optimize slow workflows
- Disable unused workflows

## Troubleshooting

### Workflow Not Triggering

Check these common issues:

- **Workflow status** - Ensure it's active
- **Trigger configuration** - Verify settings
- **Account connections** - Reauthorize if needed
- **Platform API issues** - Check platform status

### Actions Failing

Common action failures:

- **Permission issues** - Check platform permissions
- **Invalid parameters** - Review action settings
- **Rate limits** - Reduce action frequency
- **Network errors** - Temporary connectivity issues

### Unexpected Behavior

Debug workflow issues:

1. Review execution logs
2. Check condition logic
3. Verify variable values
4. Test with simple data
5. Contact support if needed

## Next Steps

- [Explore platform integrations](/docs#platform-integrations)
- [Set up analytics tracking](/docs#analytics-dashboard)
- [Learn about AI features](/docs#advanced)

Perfect! I have all the information needed for a comprehensive code review. Let me compile my findings: # Code Review: Documentation System Implementation ## Summary The documentation system has been successfully implemented with Astro Content Collections, Vue 3 components, and modal/full-page views. The architecture is solid and follows the proposal closely. However, there are **critical XSS security vulnerabilities** in markdown rendering and several missing features from the proposal that need attention. --- ## Critical Issues (Must Fix) ### 1. XSS Vulnerability in Markdown Rendering **File**: `/Users/natedamstra/socialaize/src/components/vue/docs/DocSection.vue:41-43` **Issue**: Using `v-html` with unsanitized `marked()` output creates a critical XSS vulnerability. ```vue
``` **Impact**: Malicious markdown files could inject arbitrary JavaScript and compromise user sessions. **Fix Required**: ```bash pnpm add dompurify @types/dompurify ``` ```typescript // In DocSection.vue import DOMPurify from 'dompurify'; const renderedContent = computed(() => { if (!props.doc?.body) return ''; const html = marked(props.doc.body); return DOMPurify.sanitize(html, { ALLOWED_TAGS: ['h1', 'h2', 'h3', 'h4', 'h5', 'h6', 'p', 'a', 'ul', 'ol', 'li', 'code', 'pre', 'strong', 'em', 'blockquote'], ALLOWED_ATTR: ['href', 'class', 'id'] }); }); ``` ### 2. Missing `marked` Configuration **File**: `/Users/natedamstra/socialaize/src/components/vue/docs/DocSection.vue:34` **Issue**: `marked` is used without any security configuration. No options for sanitization, no protection against XSS in links. **Fix Required**: ```typescript import { marked } from 'marked'; import DOMPurify from 'dompurify'; // Configure marked for security marked.setOptions({ headerIds: true, mangle: false, breaks: true, }); // Add link sanitization const renderer = new marked.Renderer(); const linkRenderer = renderer.link; renderer.link = (href, title, text) => { const html = linkRenderer.call(renderer, href, title, text); // Only allow http, https, and relative links if (href && !href.match(/^(https?:)?\/\//i) && !href.startsWith('#')) { return text; } return html.replace(/^ { if (!props.doc?.body) return ''; const html = marked(props.doc.body) as string; return DOMPurify.sanitize(html); }); ``` ### 3. Missing DocsModal Integration in DashLayout **File**: `/Users/natedamstra/socialaize/src/layouts/DashLayout.astro:122-127` **Status**: âœ… **ACTUALLY IMPLEMENTED** - The review request was misleading. DocsModal IS properly integrated in DashLayout with docs and categories passed correctly. --- ## High Priority Issues (Should Fix) ### 4. Missing `id` Attributes on Headings **File**: `/Users/natedamstra/socialaize/src/components/vue/docs/DocSection.vue` **Issue**: DocsLayout's table of contents script expects `id` attributes on headings, but `marked` output doesn't automatically add them unless configured. **Impact**: Table of contents links won't work (`#${heading.id}` will be undefined). **Fix**: ```typescript import { marked } from 'marked'; marked.setOptions({ headerIds: true, // Enable automatic heading IDs mangle: false // Don't mangle IDs (keep them readable) }); ``` ### 5. Missing Mobile Hamburger Menu Functionality **File**: `/Users/natedamstra/socialaize/src/layouts/DocsLayout.astro:83` **Issue**: Proposal includes hamburger menu button (`mdi:menu` icon), but no JavaScript to handle mobile menu state. **Impact**: Mobile users cannot access sidebar navigation. **Fix Required**: Add mobile menu toggle script to DocsLayout.astro or create a Vue component wrapper. ### 6. Missing Search Functionality **File**: `/Users/natedamstra/socialaize/src/layouts/DocsLayout.astro:32-40` **Issue**: Search input exists but has no functionality. Proposal mentioned Pagefind integration but it's not implemented. **Impact**: Users cannot search documentation. **Recommendation**: Either implement Pagefind (as per proposal) or remove the non-functional search box. ### 7.
